text:
Hi guys I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I want to share with

you, what I like to call my custard chocolate
rolls.

Now, this recipe was absolutely inspired by
a tweet I got when I first made, and I shared

with you my DIY vanilla pudding mix, someone
tweeted me and said 'hey, in my country, we

make vanilla pudding and we use it instead
of butter for when we make our cinnamon rolls

and we just use raisins and things like that',
and that sparked an idea in my head and I

thought I have got to try that, and of course,
I wanted to add some chocolate to it to really

make it luxurious and rich and really something
special, so I have made this recipe quite

a few times ever since because it's so good,
I even posted a picture a while ago on Instagram,

I had the whole slab, it was just gorgeous
- it's just a beautiful recipe, it's so simple

and easy, we're going to use the vanilla pudding
mix two ways, and I'll show you both ways
and they're just phenomenal.

So, the list of ingredients to make the dough
is not very big, you're going to need all

purpose flour, salt, granulated sugar, unsalted
butter that's been melted, whole milk, an

egg, some instant vanilla pudding, whether
you make your own mix or you buy it pre-made,

you just need two boxes, you need some warm
water at about 150 degrees Fahrenheit, and

then you're going to need some sugar and then
some yeast, this is active dry yeast.

Such a fabulous recipe, I can't wait to share
it with you, I'm so excited!

When something is inspired by you, it feels
- in my head I feel like this is how you guys

feel about a recipe that I post that you really
love, do you get what I'm saying?It's like

my way of seeing what you guys eat and I just
love it!
I get really excited!

Okay, the first thing we're going to do is
we need to activate the yeast, so in my warm
water, I'm going to add my sugar and my yeast.

And you just mix that together and you let
that sit for just a few minutes until the

yeast is activated and it's nice and foamy
and I'll show you what it looks like when
it's there but you just set that aside.

Now, to my flour and salt, I'm going to add
a half of cup of my vanilla pudding mix, like

I said if you don't make your own, by all
means just go to the store and buy two boxes
of this pudding mix.

For some reason, adding some of it in my dough
makes the dough so pillow-y soft and it adds
a level of vanilla sweetness that's just phenomenal.

So, adding some of that in there, giving that
a stir and I'm also going to add my sugar
at this point.
Already have the salt in there.

And now I'm going to take my dry mixture and
I am going to add that right in there like

so, and then all I need to do is wait for
my yeast to get nice and cloudy and I'll show

you what it looks like when it gets there,
and then you pretty much add everything else

in, you mix until it's perfectly combined,
so I'm going to clean up, I'm going to wait

for my yeast to be ready and I'll show you
the next step.

The yeast is ready, you can see it's nice
and foamy it's got little bubbles on the surface,

that is what we are looking for, so I am going
to just take this, add that right to my flour

mixture along with everything else, along
with the milk, the melted butter and my egg

and now all I need to do is just mix this
for about 4 to 6 minutes on medium speed,

medium to medium-low, you know every standing
mixer, or mixer in general is different so

just keep an eye on it, you want this to be
really nice soft dough, and I'll show you
what it looks like when it's there.
Okay.

You can see it's really silky, it's tacky,
borderline sticky, but that's okay, that's

what you want because if you add too much
flour, then the dough will just become too

hard and you don't want your rolls and your
buns to be hard - although maybe you do - but

you just want to get all of this off of your
beater here, off of your dough hook attachment

and I like to use a little scraper like this
and then you just get it all out into an oiled
bowl.

I just used some vegetable oil, but you can
use whatever your heart desires, it will be
perfectly fine.
Excellent.

An then all I like to do at this point is
just - I added it in and then flip it around

that way now both sides are oiled and you
don't get that weird, you know film that forms

on top of your dough, and you need to just
wrap this with some plastic wrap, stick it

somewhere warm and let it rise for about an
hour and a half to two hours or until it's
doubled in volume.

Now something else you need to do right away
once you get this rising, you need to prepare

some vanilla pudding, and I've showed you
how I do it in my homemade vanilla pudding

mix, all you do is you take a half a cup of
your vanilla pudding mix, you mix it with

two cups of whole milk on your stove top,
and you cook it just until it becomes nice

and thick for a few minutes, and then you
let it cool, pop it in the fridge to cool
completely.

It's exactly the way you would do a cook and
serve vanilla pudding mix, if you will.

So, go ahead and do that, I'm going to do
the same thing, it's really simple so I don't

need to show you that but if you want to see
exactly how I did it, go ahead and check out

my vanilla pudding mix video and I walk you
through it step-by-step, so going to get this

rising, get my vanilla pudding mix cooling
and then it'll be time to rock and roll!

We will be rolling, that made sense, most
likely in my head more than it did out here
but that's okay.

My dough has risen beautifully, it took about
two hours, and that's another thing I wanted
to mention, too.

If you ever really feel intimidated with your
dough not rising, if you know your yeast is

activated like mine was, all bubbly and stuff,
then you shouldn't have a problem.

You just need to give it time and you need
to make sure you put it in a draft free place
so that way it doesn't get disturbed.

You can roll this out with your rolling pin
if you want to, I'm just doing it by hand,

you just want it about - you want like a 15
by 9 inch rectangle, don't worry about it
too much.

Now, what I have here is my pudding that I
did, it's all ready to go, and this is some

really good quality milk chocolate and I just
pulsed this in my food processor until it
was all in smaller pieces.

You can use chocolate chips if you want to,
I have done it both ways and in my opinion,

a really good quality eating chocolate makes
all the difference, and I like milk chocolate

because it just - I don't know it just tastes
richer to me, it's my favorite.

So, that is what I'm using, you can see the
specks of vanilla from the vanilla pudding

mix running through the dough so that makes
me really happy.

Okay, so now what we need to do is we need
to take our pudding and just put it on there,
I know it looks like a lot but do not panic.

You just put this in a single layer, and then
just top it with your chocolate.

Okay, I've got my prepared pan that I just
greased with some non-stick spray.

And then just like if you were to do any kind
of cinnamon roll, user your typewriter finger,
you just fold that like so.

An then you just roll it like a jelly roll,
and then if anything escapes, you'll be fine.
Obviously, I meant a jelly roll.

Alright, then you just sort of tuck the seam
underneath.

And now you need to cut this into sixteen
pieces.

So, I just kind of cut it in half, then in

Alright, these are all cut and ready to go,

in this smaller pan because I didn't want
to cram them all in here because I'm going

to let these rest now for another 45 minutes
before I bake them so now what you need to

do is you need to cover these with some plastic
wrap, then after you have let them rest for

about 45 minutes, bake them at 350 degrees
F for about 30 to 40 minutes or so or until

golden brown and I'll show you what they look
like when they are done.

So, all I'm going to do is just cover, let

and you'll notice my hair is up and that's
